mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Delta(f)(x)=\sum_{e\in E,o(e)=x}(f(t(e))-f(o(e)))." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>E</mi></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>e</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></munder><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>e</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>e</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\sum_{e\in X_{0}}x.(\phi(t(e^{\prime}))-\phi(o(e^{\prime}))(\phi(t(e^{\prime})%
)-\phi(o(e^{\prime}))=cx\,\,,\forall x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}" display="block"><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>X</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow></munder><mi>x</mi><mo>.</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ϕ</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>ϕ</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>o</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ϕ</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>ϕ</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>o</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>c</mi><mpadded width="+3.4pt"><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>,</mo><mo>∀</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><msup><mi>ℝ</mi><mi>n</mi></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
for positive definite symmetric $m\times m$ matrices $A(e)$(this is an extra, but useful condition), $ m=card(E_0) $,  and masses $m(x)$ associated to atoms $x\in V$. Physicists call $A$,  the matrix of atomic force constants.
$D$
is an $L$-equivariant linear bounded self-adjoint
operator on the  Hilbert space generated by the space $C(V,\mathbb{C}^n)$  equipped with the inner product $<f,g>=\sum_{x\in V} f(x).\overline{g(x)}m(x)$. 

\subsection {Hamiltonian formalism of the motion equation} In this section a Hamiltonian formalism is used to provide a  decomposition of a vibration to simpler harmonic vibrations \cite{ss}.
Let $w:l^2(V,m)\times  l^2(V,m)\rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a symplectic form on
$l^2(V,m)=\{\sum_{x\in V}|f(x)|^2m(x)<\infty\}$ defined by $w(u,v)=Im<u,v>=Im( \sum_{x\in V}u(x)v(x)m(x))$. Let $H(u) =\frac{1}{2}<(-D)^{\frac{1}{2}}u, u>$.
Let $ \widehat{L}$ be the unitary character group of $ L$, and $d\chi$ denotes the normalized Haar
measure on $ \widehat{L}$. Then
the Bloch decomposition of the Hamiltonian system $(l^2(V,m),w,H)$ is
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="Df(x)=\frac{1}{m(x)}\sum_{e\in E_{x}}A(e)(f(t(e))-f(o(e)))" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>D</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>x</mi></msub></mrow></munder><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>e</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>e</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>e</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where $l^2(V,m)_\chi=\{u\in l^2(V,m)|u(\sigma x)=\chi(\sigma)u(x)\,, \forall \sigma \in L\}$. In fact, the elements $\chi \in \widehat{L} $ are the same as the angular frequencies. Using the index $\chi$ for an operator means that we restrict its domain to the  vector space $l^2(V,m)_\chi$.
Note that we have a decomposition of $D$ as $\int_{\widehat{L}}^\bigoplus D_\chi  d\chi$. The operators $-D_\chi , \, \chi\ne 1$ are positive definite.
Zero is an eigenvalue of $âD_1$ of multiplicity $n$ with constant eigenfunctions.\\
For the eigenmodes (eigenfunctions) corresponding to the first $n$ eigenvalues of $D_\chi$, neighboring atoms move in phase with each other with the same amplitude and each of which is called an $\mathbf{acoustic\, phase}$. The velocity of these phases is called the acoustic phase velocity.
It is equal to $\frac{1}{2\pi\parallel{\chi}\parallel}s_i(\chi),\, i=1,...,n$, where one can prove
\begin{theorem}\label{3} $s_i(\chi)^2\,\,\,(i = 1, \dots, n)$ are eigenvalues of the symmetric
	matrix

for positive definite symmetric $m\times m$ matrices $A(e)$(this is an extra, but useful condition), $ m=card(E_0) $,  and masses $m(x)$ associated to atoms $x\in V$. Physicists call $A$,  the matrix of atomic force constants.
$D$
is an $L$-equivariant linear bounded self-adjoint
operator on the  Hilbert space generated by the space $C(V,\mathbb{C}^n)$  equipped with the inner product $<f,g>=\sum_{x\in V} f(x).\overline{g(x)}m(x)$. 

\subsection {Hamiltonian formalism of the motion equation} In this section a Hamiltonian formalism is used to provide a  decomposition of a vibration to simpler harmonic vibrations \cite{ss}.
Let $w:l^2(V,m)\times  l^2(V,m)\rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a symplectic form on
$l^2(V,m)=\{\sum_{x\in V}|f(x)|^2m(x)<\infty\}$ defined by $w(u,v)=Im<u,v>=Im( \sum_{x\in V}u(x)v(x)m(x))$. Let $H(u) =\frac{1}{2}<(-D)^{\frac{1}{2}}u, u>$.
Let $ \widehat{L}$ be the unitary character group of $ L$, and $d\chi$ denotes the normalized Haar
measure on $ \widehat{L}$. Then
the Bloch decomposition of the Hamiltonian system $(l^2(V,m),w,H)$ is
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="(l^{2}(V,m),w,H)=\int_{\widehat{L}}^{\bigoplus}(l^{2}(V,m)_{\chi},w_{\chi},H_{%
\chi})d\chi\,," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msup><mi>l</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>V</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>m</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi>w</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>H</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>L</mi><mo>^</mo></mover><mstyle scriptlevel="-1"><mo largeop="true" mathsize="160%" stretchy="false" symmetric="true">⊕</mo></mstyle></msubsup><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msup><mi>l</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>V</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>m</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mi>χ</mi></msub></mrow><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>w</mi><mi>χ</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>χ</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>χ</mi></mpadded></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
where $l^2(V,m)_\chi=\{u\in l^2(V,m)|u(\sigma x)=\chi(\sigma)u(x)\,, \forall \sigma \in L\}$. In fact, the elements $\chi \in \widehat{L} $ are the same as the angular frequencies. Using the index $\chi$ for an operator means that we restrict its domain to the  vector space $l^2(V,m)_\chi$.
Note that we have a decomposition of $D$ as $\int_{\widehat{L}}^\bigoplus D_\chi  d\chi$. The operators $-D_\chi , \, \chi\ne 1$ are positive definite.
Zero is an eigenvalue of $âD_1$ of multiplicity $n$ with constant eigenfunctions.\\
For the eigenmodes (eigenfunctions) corresponding to the first $n$ eigenvalues of $D_\chi$, neighboring atoms move in phase with each other with the same amplitude and each of which is called an $\mathbf{acoustic\, phase}$. The velocity of these phases is called the acoustic phase velocity.
It is equal to $\frac{1}{2\pi\parallel{\chi}\parallel}s_i(\chi),\, i=1,...,n$, where one can prove
\begin{theorem}\label{3} $s_i(\chi)^2\,\,\,(i = 1, \dots, n)$ are eigenvalues of the symmetric
	matrix
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="A_{\chi}:=\frac{2\pi^{2}}{m(V_{0})}\sum_{e\in E_{0}}(\chi.v(e))^{2}A(e)." display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>χ</mi></msub><mo>:=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>π</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow></munder><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>χ</mi><mo>.</mo><mi>v</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>e</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>e</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\\ Equip each of these tori with the natural Euclidean metric. The length of  closed geodesics of  $\widehat{L}$ are the same as the eigenvalues of the Laplace-Beltrami Operator on the torus $\frac{\mathbb{R}^n}{L}$. Let us integrate $s_i(\chi)^2$ over simple closed geodesics including $1$. We call this the integrated acoustic velocity.
A natural question arising here is: \\\\ $\mathbf{What \,is\, the\, ralation\, between\, integrated \, acoustic\, velocity\, of\, the \, crystal\, lattice \,}$ $C$\,$\mathbf{ and \,the\, }$\\  $\mathbf{ \,Laplacian \,eigenvalues\, of\, the \,torus \, }
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="L^{*}=\{x\,|\,x.y\in\mathbb{Z},\,\forall y\in L\}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>L</mi><mo>*</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>.</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>ℤ</mi></mrow><mo rspace="4.2pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>∀</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mo>∈</mo><mi>L</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
\\ Equip each of these tori with the natural Euclidean metric. The length of  closed geodesics of  $\widehat{L}$ are the same as the eigenvalues of the Laplace-Beltrami Operator on the torus $\frac{\mathbb{R}^n}{L}$. Let us integrate $s_i(\chi)^2$ over simple closed geodesics including $1$. We call this the integrated acoustic velocity.
A natural question arising here is: \\\\ $\mathbf{What \,is\, the\, ralation\, between\, integrated \, acoustic\, velocity\, of\, the \, crystal\, lattice \,}$ $C$\,$\mathbf{ and \,the\, }$\\  $\mathbf{ \,Laplacian \,eigenvalues\, of\, the \,torus \, }
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\{\int_{c}\sum_{i=1}^{n}s_{i}(\chi)^{2}d\chi|c\in T\}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mrow><msub><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi>c</mi></msub><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>n</mi></munderover><mrow><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>χ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>χ</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

text:
$$\mathbf{ lattice\, C?}\,\,(**)$
\begin{theorem}\label{nn} Consider m vectors $v_i=v(e_i), i=1,\cdots,m$ where $v(e_i)=\phi (t({e_i}))-\phi(e{(e_i)})$.  Assume $|v_i|=1$ and $trA(e_i)=\frac{
		3}{2\pi^2}m(V_0),\,\, i=1,\cdots,m$. Then the acoustic spectrum is equal with $Asp=\{\sum_i(\chi.v_i)^2 |\chi \in L\}$.
	\end {theorem}
	Proof: The therorem  is a result of the fact that  the summation $\sum_{i=1}^n s_i(\chi)^2$ is the trace of the matrix $A_\chi$(Theorem \ref{3}) and the fact that 
	$ \int_c\sum_{i=1}^n s_i(\chi)^2=\sum_{i=1}\int_0^1s_i(t\chi)^2dt=\sum_{i=1}\int_0^1s_i(t\chi)^2dt=\int_0^1t^2s_i(\chi)^2dt=\frac{2\pi^2}{
		3m(V_0)}
	\sum_{e\in E_0}(\chi.v(e_i))^2trA(e_i)$.
	\\\\The problem $(**)$  can be written as follows,\\
	\hspace{2cm} Let $Asp=\{\sum_i(\chi.v_i)^2 |\chi \in L\}$,  can we determine the set $Lsp=\{|\chi| | \chi \in L\}?$ 
	\begin{theorem}\label{43} Under the assumptions of Theorem \ref{nn}, the $Asp$ determine the lengths of elements of $L$ and ${L}^*$ up to a constant $c$.  
	\end{theorem} Proof: According to the property \ref{se} of a standard realization, $\sum_i(\chi.v_i)^2=c|\chi|^2$. On the other hand from the Poisson formula we have  $ \sum_{y\in L^*}
	e^{-4\pi^2 {|y|}^2t}=\frac{Volume(L)}{{(4\pi t)}^\frac{n}{2}}\sum_{s\in L}
	e^{-\frac{{|s|}^2}{4t}}$ which provides the relation between lengths of elements of $L$ and $L^*$.\\
	The physical interpretation of Theorem \ref{43} is that when the average of quantities $(A(e)x.x)$ on the unit sphere (which is a divergence like quantity )  are the same for  neighboring atoms and the crystal laies in its harmonic position,  the integrating of velocities ($s_i(\chi)$) of independent acoustic phases over the closed geodesics of the angular momentum phase space determine the length of elements of the symmetric lattice of the crystal up to a constant. 
	\subsection{Generalized problem }
	In this  subsection we consider examples for a more general case.  We ignore that the set of vectors $v_i,\,\, i=1,...,n$ are obtained from a lattice harmonic embedding. Moreover we assume some extra assumptions about our lattice.\\
	Example 1: Let $v_1,v_2,v_3$ be an orthogonal basis of $\mathbb{R}^3$ and $v_4$ makes angle $120^\circ$ with  each vector $v_1,v_2,v_3$. Also let the position of $v_4$ is such that $\chi.v_4\in \mathbb{Q}^c$ for  $\chi \in L$. Then the set $Asp$ is equal to $\{|\chi|^2(1+cos^2\theta_{4\chi})|\chi \in L\}$ where $cos^2\theta_{4\chi}$ is irrational for all  $\chi \in L$ which denotes the angle between $\chi$ and $v_4$. We can obtain candidates for  $Lsp$'s by dividing each element of the set $Asp$ by the  numbers in the interval $(1,2)$ which generate  integer numbers and then computing the square root of them.\\\\
	Example 2:
	In this example let us conceive some extra knowledge about $L$ and the vectors $v_i,\,\,i=1,\cdots,n.$  Suppose  we know there are four basic atoms in each cell of a crystal and one of them is jointed with the others.
	Therefore, we have three vectors and assume they have the same length 1.  Furthermore suppose that there is a number $k$ such that $kL$ is an integral lattice generated by two vectors of the same length. Concisely 
	let $L=\{k\chi +l\eta: k,l\in \mathbb{Z}\}$ and
	$|\eta|=|\chi|.$\\
	
	By these conditions we have $$
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="Asp=|\chi|^{2}\{k^{2}(\sum_{i=1}^{3}cos^{2}\theta_{i\chi})+l^{2}(\sum_{i=1}^{3%
}cos^{2}\theta_{i\eta})+2kl(\sum_{i=1}^{3}cos\theta_{i\chi}cos\theta_{i\eta})|%
k,l\in\mathbb{Z}\}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>p</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>χ</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>3</mn></munderover><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>χ</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msup><mi>l</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>3</mn></munderover><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>η</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>3</mn></munderover><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>χ</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>η</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow><mo>∈</mo><mi>ℤ</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

$$ where $\theta_{i\chi}$ and $\theta_{i\eta}$
	are respectively  the angles of $v_i$ with $\chi$ and $eta$. Assume that  $\sum_{i=1}^3cos\theta_{i\chi}cos\theta_{i\eta}$ be a positive number, then the minimum  of the set $\frac{T}{|\chi|^2}$  is equal to  $$
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="min\{(\sum_{i=1}^{3}cos^{2}\theta_{i\chi}),(\sum_{i=1}^{3}cos^{2}\theta_{i\eta%
})\}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>3</mn></munderover><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>χ</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>3</mn></munderover><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>η</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\sum_{i=1}^3cos^2\theta_{i\eta}=\beta,\sum_{i=1}^3cos\theta_{i\chi}cos\theta_{i\eta}=\gamma,\sum_{i=1}^3cos^2\theta_{i\chi}=\alpha.$$ A simple geometric discussion on the angles provide a description of the set $Lsp$.

$$ Now , assume that we know all solutions of the next algebraic problem.\\
	Problem.Let $\mathbb{Z}*\mathbb{Z} =\{x^2|x\in \mathbb{Z}\}$ and $\mathbb{Z}. \mathbb{Z}=\{x.y |x,y\in \mathbb{Z}\}$.
	Suppose that $m\in \mathbb{Z}$, $\alpha,\beta,\gamma \in \mathbb{R}^+$, and assume that we know the set $M=\{m(\alpha \mathbb{Z}*\mathbb{Z}+\beta \mathbb{Z}*\mathbb{Z} +\gamma \mathbb{Z}. \mathbb{Z})\}$. Find all four tuple $(m,\alpha,\beta,\gamma)$ with the same $M$.\\\
	For each 3 tuples $(\alpha,\beta,\gamma)$ we must find the  set of  solutions for the set of equations  $$
